case_title: SOHAIL AHMAD SHEIKH vs SECRETARY; HOME AND TRIBAL AFFAIRS, GOVERNMENT OF BALOCHISTAN, QUETTA and 5 others

respondant.name: Secretary, Home and Tribal Affairs, Government of Balochistan, Quetta

complaint_summary: The appellant challenged the seniority list issued on 1-8-1997, alleging unjust regularization of respondents' services from their ad hoc appointment dates, which placed them ahead of him in seniority despite his regular appointment.
investigation_summary: The appellant's objections to the seniority list were not addressed by the authorities. Respondents were regularized from their ad hoc appointment dates despite failing Public Service Commission tests, violating rules and causing undue favor.

judgment_summary.issue: Seniority dispute between appellant and respondents Nos. 4 to 6.
judgment_summary.appellant_claim: Appellant claimed seniority based on regular appointment through Public Service Commission.
judgment_summary.respondents_claim: Respondents claimed seniority based on retrospective regularization of ad hoc appointments.

tribunal_findings.seniority_list: The seniority list dated 1-8-1992, showing appellant senior to respondents, was deemed final.
tribunal_findings.notification: The impugned notification dated 19-10-1993, regularizing respondents from their ad hoc appointment dates, was declared illegal and void.
tribunal_findings.principle_of_law: Ad hoc appointments do not confer seniority rights over regular appointments.

judgment_summary.decision: The Tribunal declared the appellant senior to respondents Nos. 4 to 6, set aside the impugned notification dated 19-10-1993, and directed the correction of the seniority list dated 1-8-1997 to reflect the appellant's rightful position.

punishment: Impugned notification dated 19-10-1993 set aside; seniority list corrected.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal accepted. Appellant declared senior to respondents Nos. 4 to 6.
legal_arguments: Ad hoc appointments do not confer seniority rights.
Regular appointments take precedence over ad hoc appointments.
Government's retrospective regularization violated rules and fundamental rights.
statutes: Balochistan Civil Servants (Appointment, Promotion and Transfer) Rules, 1979
sections: Section 2(a) of Balochistan Civil Servants Act, 1974
Rule 18 and Rule 19 of Balochistan Civil Servants Rules, 1979
Rule 5 of Balochistan Public Service Commission Rules, 1982
key_issues: Validity of retrospective regularization of ad hoc appointments.
Violation of seniority rules and fundamental rights.
Maintainability of appeal against seniority list.

words_and_phrases.Seniority list: A list determining the hierarchy of employees based on service rules.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around seniority disputes between a regular appointee and ad hoc appointees in the police department. The Tribunal ruled in favor of the appellant, emphasizing adherence to rules and fairness in seniority determination.

directions.seniority_list: Authorities directed to correct seniority list dated 1-8-1997.
